1666830303648956416.text:
Replit AI Manifesto

This manifesto is the culmination of a conversation @amasad and I have had for over a year on the future of AI and its impact on the software industry.

I decided to join @Replit as VP of AI because I want to turn our shared vision into reality.

1/ ğŸ§µ https://t.co/9boL0wfhis

1666837226976870403.text:
A new meaning to REPL.

This novel feedback loop sits at the core of the Replit ADI. We call it the â€œReflect, Evaluate, Percolate and Learnâ€ loop â€“ a whole new meaning to REPL. The agentic behavior of our ADI wonâ€™t be limited by what recent LLMs can do, but will rather keepâ€¦ https://t.co/Z8kXeNrAC1

1666837905703342080.text:
A new quote for the Replit yearbook.

Our company history, since 2016, is one of steady and tangible growth rather than of chasing the hype â€“ itâ€™s deeply rooted in our culture. We can see the road ahead that will lead us to ADI, and we are paving the way for it â€“ line of code byâ€¦

1666836698263871488.text:
Building the Replit ADI is the most ambitious project we have ever undertaken. 

In spite of the meteoric rise of LLMs, we are deeply aware of the many challenges they still entail (for instance, hallucinations). Our focus on code, though, allows us to lift the LLM input/outputâ€¦ https://t.co/x2mUZbHXnH

1666211786742435843.text:
RT @amasad: Thrilled to welcome @pirroh to the team at @Replit as VP of AI. 

This manifesto is a culmination of a year-long conversation wâ€¦

1663366478094270464.text:
When it comes to LLMs, it's easy to build products, but not easy to maintain them -- progress is so fast-paced that it's hard to predict if what works today will still be the best approach by end of year.
Still, In-Context Learning + Retrieval work great for now! Let's build ğŸš€

1663366223491645440.text:
We already see a bimodal distribution:
ğŸ‘‰ "giant" LLMs keep improving, supporting as many use cases as possible, but trading off on $ and latency ğŸ‘‰ "specialized" LLMs have narrower scope, but better $ and latency

Equally useful. Matter of fact, Ghostwriter leverages both!

1663364701223550976.text:
It's getting easier by the day to fine tune LLMs! For example, QLora on a 65B LLM with a single 48GB GPU: https://t.co/a7UHsVAdJ9 

Training LLMs from scratch like we did at @Replit
is certainly more work, but companies like @MosaicML and @huggingface make it way more accessible.

1663363672826351616.text:
LLMs still struggle with program semantics, so I'm skeptical on their ability to predict program execution, aside of toy examples.
That said,  training on code + error traces made LLMs  an invaluable debugging tool -- Ghostwriter Chat  supports that!
ğŸ§µ 1/2

1663363880209481730.text:
As evidence, check this recent paper:
https://t.co/jzLMcbWhTh
ğŸ§µ 2/2

1663363319233929216.text:
The main challenge for LLM interoperability is the lack of a standardized "protocol" -- different LLMs require different prompting to achieve the best possible performance.
@LangChainAI built a great abstraction layer, but updating the prompts on new LLM releases is still on us!

1349237578596114432.text:
ğŸ”¦ (Highlight Of The Day) HOTD 01/12 - #CS224W Lecture 1

Graph Machine Learninng â€” two sides of the same coin.
- why is it one of the most exciting research areas in ML? (the Good)
- why is it a hard technical problem? (the Bad)

1349237592382865408.text:
The Bad â€” why Graph ML is hard?

The modern Deep Learning toolbox is designed for sequences and grids. Graphs lack the regular structure leveraged by models like RNNs and CNNs. As such, applying modern ML to graphs required a brand new paradigm â€” Graph Neural Networks (GNNs). https://t.co/T4rozu3cg1

1349237593779494915.text:
Eager to learn more?
Check the slide deck from Lecture 1: https://t.co/FE8sP9KaKn

And stay tuned for new #CS224W highlights on Thu!

1348837702980890628.text: This quarter Iâ€™m advising 2 @Stanford courses: CS224W â€œML with Graphsâ€ and CS329S â€œML Systems Designâ€ (respectively taught by @jure and @chipro). To break my bad habit of being dormant on Twitter, Iâ€™ll tweet some highlights after every lecture!

1349225851586371585.text: We plan to release a video series on YouTube for the whole CS224W course. Just allow us some time for editing and captioning â€” Iâ€™ll announce it on Twitter ASAP! /cc @SanjogMehta @gurdeepmaurya @ML_DL_eng @sAliAlavi

1348842944250273792.text:
6 myths of ML Systems in production:

1.  Deploying models (w/o SLAs) is hard
2. You only deploy a handful models at a time
3.  Model performance remains the same over time

#cs329s

1348842944975958017.text:
4.  You wonâ€™t need to redeploy your models as much
5.  Most ML engineers donâ€™t need to worry about scale
6.  ML can magically transform your business overnight

#cs329s

1348844229129236484.text:
A great resource to debunk myth #3 is WILDS: a benchmark of in-the-wild distribution shifts spanning diverse data modalities and applications, from tumor identification to wildlife monitoring to poverty mapping.

https://t.co/YxrLCLg9nq

1004081515712602112.text: @MasterScrat Exactly! And it wouldn't be that hard -- as an example: "[...] We assume we can identify an author's gender if the author's first name is associated with a single gender in social security records at least 95% of the time. [...]" https://t.co/rFZVodPkhw

1003704994913112064.text: This is a common high risk / low return scenario in data science: misclassifications are glaring, but the mail would have been routed even w/o the useless gendered title!

Towards an Artificial Developer Intelligence.

At Replit, we are rethinking from the ground up the developer experience, with AI as a first-class citizen of the development environment. To this end, we have been working daily to build an ADI â€“ Artificial Developer Intelligence.â€¦
